Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Understanding the Collective Effects in Suspensions of Vesicles, Capsules, and Particles

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
Award: 1066263
PI: Shaqfeh/Muller

This project represents a comprehensive investigation of the individual dynamics and the collective interactions of vesicles, capsules, and capsule/particle mixtures. The collaborative research is a synergistic effort between high performance computer (HPC) simulations of multiphase flow phenomena as well as detailed experiments using microfluidics and microrheology. Novel aspects of the simulation algorithm include a smooth particle mesh Ewald boundary element code employing both spectral, Loop subdivision, and boundary element resolution of the deforming and interacting interfaces. Essentially, arbitrary shear, bending, and dilatational moduli in the interfacial modeling can be included thus allowing the full range of dynamics from capsules to vesicles including rigid particles and mixtures to be simulated in complex microfluidic geometries. Moreover, nonBrownian and Brownian suspensions can be simulated with high resolution of the interfaces. The experiments include direct visualization, via fluorescence microscopy, of the detailed time varying dynamics of vesicles, and, by creative interfacial chemistry, capsules with varying shear modulus in (a) the microfluidic four roll mill device (capable of reproducing any planar mixed flow in the vicinity of a stagnation point at which the vesicle/capsule may be trapped and observed for extended times) and (b) microchannel geometries designed for examination of collective suspension dynamics. Experiments will also focus on measurements, through fluorescence microscopy and particle tracking, of the shear-induced diffusion of particles and the rheological behavior as the confinement length scale is varied. Applications including understanding platelet hemostasis in the microcirculation as well as engineering vesicles for medical applications.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The proposed study included an investigation of the individual dynamics and the collective interactions of vesicles, capsules, and capsule/particle mixtures. The collaborative research (with collaborator Eric S.G. Shaqfeh at Stanford University) represented a synergistic effort between high performance computer  (HPC) simulations (at Stanford) of multiphase flow phenomena as well as detailed experiments (at Berkeley) using microfluidics and microrheology. The experiments included (a) generation and characterization of a library of monodisperse particles and vesicles of varying size, deformability, and shape, (b) direct visualization, via fluorescence microscopy, of the detailed time varying dynamics of vesicles in a microfluidic cross slot device and (c) observation of particles and vesicles in microchannel geometries designed for examination of collective suspension dynamics.

The intellectual merit of the work included 1) the development of strategies for quickly producing prototype microfluidic devices, 2) the development and evaluation of strategies for producing a library of monodisperse particles of varying size, deformability, and shape via microfluidic drop formation methods (figure 1), 3) the evaluation of routes to producing monodisperse vesicles, 4) preliminary measurements of particle migration in microchannels, and 5) experimental validation of a shape instability for vesicles in extensional flow predicted by our collaborators at Stanford (figure 2).  We have also characterized the shear and compressive moduli of the particles we have created, and measured the bending modulus for the vesicles used.

We anticipate that the rapid prototyping protocols we have developed, which are much faster than conventional soft lithography and require significantly less training and equipment, will prove useful to others engaged in microfluidics research. We also believe the particle library we have created will be useful for future studies.  Although the accessible capillary numbers (ratio of viscous to elastic forces) with the solid elastic particles are too low to observe deformation and significant migration in channel flows at low Reynolds numbers, the particle library will be valuable for other studies, for example to examine both shear induced migration at high concentrations and inertial migration in the dilute regime. Optimization of the generation of non-spherical particles will allow us to examine the effect of particle shape on particle interactions and migration length.

Ultimately, we anticipate studies using the particles and vesicles will lead to a better understanding of the collective effects of vesicle/capsule mixtures that are critical to engineering them for drug delivery applications.  The project has also facilitated the training of two female post-doctoral scientists, two female graduate students, and six undergraduates.
